linkTarget.anchoringText: The Kita-Akita oil field is one of the satellite fields of main Yabase Oil Fields (Hirai et al., 1990), which developed from the early 1900s and has produced 5.8 million bbls of oil and 1.4 billion scf of natural gas cumulatively (equivalent to 36.5 million bbls of oil and 51.8 billion scf of natural gas), located in Akita region, Northern Japan (Fig. 1). The satellite field (approximately 3 × 3 km2) produced from 1957 to 1973 and all produced wells were plugged and abandoned. However, the past study shows the recovery rate is approximately a few %. A task force was organized and a series of programs including the data acquisition (e.g., Fig. 2A and 2B) and the feasibility study were conducted to test the sub-commercial field redevelopment.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: (A) Index Map of the Kita-Akita oil field. (B) The main reservoir structure map of the Kita-Akita field locating on the north-south anticlines demonstrating the structure and stratigraphic combination trap.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) Index Map of the Kita-Akita oil field. (B) The main reservoir structure map of the Kita-Akita field locating on the north-south anticlines demonstrating the structure and stratigraphic combination trap.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Index Map of the Kita-Akita oil field
The main reservoir structure map of the Kita-Akita field locating on the north-south anticlines demonstrating the structure and stratigraphic combination trap

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Kita-Akita oil field is one of the satellite fields of main Yabase Oil Fields (Hirai et al., 1990), which developed from the early 1900s and has produced 5.8 million bbls of oil and 1.4 billion scf of natural gas cumulatively (equivalent to 36.5 million bbls of oil and 51.8 billion scf of natural gas), located in Akita region, Northern Japan (Fig. 1). The satellite field (approximately 3 × 3 km2) produced from 1957 to 1973 and all produced wells were plugged and abandoned. However, the past study shows the recovery rate is approximately a few %. A task force was organized and a series of programs including the data acquisition (e.g., Fig. 2A and 2B) and the feasibility study were conducted to test the sub-commercial field redevelopment.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: The outcrop and the pilot hole data acquisition led to revisit the geological concept. (A) The outcrop at a distance of a few km from the Kita-Akita Field shows the tuffaceous sandstone forms the lenticular geometry. (B) The conventional core in the reservoir interval displays abundant erosional and sliding surfaces providing the evidence of deepwater slope depositional environment. (C) Schematic depositional environment of the Kita-Akita oil field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The outcrop and the pilot hole data acquisition led to revisit the geological concept. (A) The outcrop at a distance of a few km from the Kita-Akita Field shows the tuffaceous sandstone forms the lenticular geometry. (B) The conventional core in the reservoir interval displays abundant erosional and sliding surfaces providing the evidence of deepwater slope depositional environment. (C) Schematic depositional environment of the Kita-Akita oil field.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: The outcrop at a distance of a few km from the Kita-Akita Field shows the tuffaceous sandstone forms the lenticular geometry
The conventional core in the reservoir interval displays abundant erosional and sliding surfaces providing the evidence of deepwater slope depositional environment
Schematic depositional environment of the Kita-Akita oil field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 3 illustrates the general overview of the impact of permeability on conventional completion and stimulation decisions (Schlumberger Oil field review, 2000). The area highlighted in yellow in Fig. 3 has enough permeability to flow naturally from matrix, thus an enhancement or remediation is usually performed for the purpose of a damage removal by matrix acidizing. Other areas correspond to low permeability reservoirs which typically require hydraulic fracturing.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: General overview of the impact of permeability on completion and stimulation decisions ( Schlumberger Oil field review, 2000 ). The Kita-Akita reservoir exhibits a wide permeability range (red line) due to its highly heterogeneous sandstones.

formatted-caption.caption-text: General overview of the impact of permeability on completion and stimulation decisions ( Schlumberger Oil field review, 2000 ). The Kita-Akita reservoir exhibits a wide permeability range (red line) due to its highly heterogeneous sandstones.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To select a best completion and stimulation candidate from multiple methods, we constructed a score matrix as shown in Fig. 4, where vertical and lateral axes show the type of well and each type of completion and well stimulation methods, respectively. Each box corresponding to the type of well and type of completion and stimulation has sub-boxes divided into four categories, namely, maturity, applicability, productivity, and economics. Each sub-box will be filled up with scores (1 through 4, for example).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Score Matrix for screening best candidate, which is specially made for the Kita-Akita field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Score Matrix for screening best candidate, which is specially made for the Kita-Akita field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 5 illustrates the workflow. Once the resevoir model is calibrated with production history in static and dynamic modeling, geomechanical modeling was conducted to create a 3D MEM (Mechanical Earth Model) to provide stress field information for wellbore stability analysis and hydraulic fracturing simulation. The 3D MEM was calibrated with a 1D MEM of the pilot-hole, which was constructed from log-based geomechanical data and tied to a set of laboratory rock mechanics tests, wellbore images and drilling events. The calibrated stress field is utilized in our stimulation and completion screening study afterwards.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Integrated Workflow. Static, dynamic modeling, 3D MEM constructed model was used for well candidate screening study.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Integrated Workflow. Static, dynamic modeling, 3D MEM constructed model was used for well candidate screening study.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir model is formed as the sector model (1.5 km to 2km) focusing the Kita-Akita channel belt. The grid size was set up in 20 m × 20 m with proportional 60 layers on approximately the 40 m reservoir interval. Three rock types in the formation are formed; sand and fine sand as reservoir, and mud as non-reservoir. To address the uncertainty of highly heterogeneous sandstone distribution, the Sequential Indicator Simulation (SIS) and the Multiple-Point Statistics (MPS) simulation (e.g., Strebelle et al., 2002) methods were applied (Fig. 6A). Permeabilities of sand and fine sand facies were calibrated with well data showing two orders of magnitude difference between them (Fig. 7).
linkTarget.label: Figure 6

image-wrap.caption: (A) 2D plain views of three geological facies models. Left, center and right figures show MPS channel model, MPS sheet model and SIS model, respectively. (B) Mobile oil saturation maps for MPS channel model and MPS sheet model. The low saturated center regions are caused by the gas caps. Both western and eastern sides deepen below the regional OWC.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) 2D plain views of three geological facies models. Left, center and right figures show MPS channel model, MPS sheet model and SIS model, respectively. (B) Mobile oil saturation maps for MPS channel model and MPS sheet model. The low saturated center regions are caused by the gas caps. Both western and eastern sides deepen below the regional OWC.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: 2D plain views of three geological facies models. Left, center and right figures show MPS channel model, MPS sheet model and SIS model, respectively
Mobile oil saturation maps for MPS channel model and MPS sheet model. The low saturated center regions are caused by the gas caps. Both western and eastern sides deepen below the regional OWC

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir model is formed as the sector model (1.5 km to 2km) focusing the Kita-Akita channel belt. The grid size was set up in 20 m × 20 m with proportional 60 layers on approximately the 40 m reservoir interval. Three rock types in the formation are formed; sand and fine sand as reservoir, and mud as non-reservoir. To address the uncertainty of highly heterogeneous sandstone distribution, the Sequential Indicator Simulation (SIS) and the Multiple-Point Statistics (MPS) simulation (e.g., Strebelle et al., 2002) methods were applied (Fig. 6A). Permeabilities of sand and fine sand facies were calibrated with well data showing two orders of magnitude difference between them (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: N-S directional cross-sectional view of three permeability models. Upper and Lower figures show MPS channel model and MPS sheet model, respectively. The cube is horizontally flattened.

formatted-caption.caption-text: N-S directional cross-sectional view of three permeability models. Upper and Lower figures show MPS channel model and MPS sheet model, respectively. The cube is horizontally flattened.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Multiple realizations formed by each MPS scienario were screened with history matching of the past production data of the Kita-Akita field (Fig. 8) and the single realization was chosen for the each MPS model (Figs 6&7). The SIS model exhibits highly discontinuous distribution (Fig. 6A, right). As a result, a higher reservoir Net-to-Gross ratio was needed to match the historical production data, relative to the actual well data. Therefore, the SIS model was considered to be inconsistent. The history-matched realizations from the two MPS cases demonstrated distinctive reservoir distributions. The channel and the sheet models from the MPS show vertically and laterally connected distributions, respectively (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: History matched production profiles (Left; MPS channel model. Right; MPS sheet model).

formatted-caption.caption-text: History matched production profiles (Left; MPS channel model. Right; MPS sheet model).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The subsurface regions surrounding the reservoir is of 6 × 4.5 × 4.5 km, forming the computational volume included in the 3DMEM and shown in Fig. 9. Based on a seismic interpretation of a set of 2D lines, two faults and the main stratigraphic seismic horizon from a ground level below the reservoir of the target were incorporated. Based on previous studies mapping the stress field at a regional scale, the long side of the model aligned with the direction of maximum tectonic strain. The direction is approximately N135°E. From outcrop analogs and initial 1D geomechanics modeling results, fracture height containment was a concern from the apparent lack of vertical stress barriers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Overview of 3D mechanical earth model. The reservoir (blue square) is embedded within the surrounding formations and where mechanical properties distributed everywhere in the model. The stress solution is obtained by means of finite element simulations, where boundary conditions are adjusted until results along the pilot hole match those obtained in the 1D MEM.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Overview of 3D mechanical earth model. The reservoir (blue square) is embedded within the surrounding formations and where mechanical properties distributed everywhere in the model. The stress solution is obtained by means of finite element simulations, where boundary conditions are adjusted until results along the pilot hole match those obtained in the 1D MEM.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The input properties such as Young's modulus, Poisson's ratio, bulk density, Biot's coefficient, unconfined compressive strength, and friction angle were populated along layers using log-derived properties in a pilot hole. The geomechanical properties in the reservoir region were distributed by allowing for dependency to reservoir model facies (sand, fine sand, and shale). The correlation between facies and geomechanical properties were estimated from extensive laboratory tests on the pilot hole. Geomechanical properties along the pilot hole are shown in Fig. 10. Curves in pink and bars in colors indicate the values of log and model, respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Profiles of geomechanical properties along a pilot hole (Pink lines are log values and bars are modeled values. YM: Young's modulus. PR: Poisson's ratio. UCS: Unconfined compressive strength. Dots in gray are the data measured at laboratory).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Profiles of geomechanical properties along a pilot hole (Pink lines are log values and bars are modeled values. YM: Young's modulus. PR: Poisson's ratio. UCS: Unconfined compressive strength. Dots in gray are the data measured at laboratory).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The magnitude of the overburden stress, the maximum and minimum horizontal stresses are shown in Fig. 11. Regarding comparison of the magnitude of the stress, the stress regime changes from the reverse faulting regime to strike-slip faulting regime with depth. In the reservoir section, the strike-slip faulting regime was interpreted. The contrast in the magnitude of Shmin between the reservoir section and the intervals above and below the reservoir is not significant. The direction of the minimum principal stress (S3) in the reservoir region is shown in Fig. 12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Magnitude of stresses along a pilot hole (Black lines are log values and bars are modeled values. Triangles in red and gray are LOT and fracture closure pressure in DFIT respectively).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Magnitude of stresses along a pilot hole (Black lines are log values and bars are modeled values. Triangles in red and gray are LOT and fracture closure pressure in DFIT respectively).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The magnitude of the overburden stress, the maximum and minimum horizontal stresses are shown in Fig. 11. Regarding comparison of the magnitude of the stress, the stress regime changes from the reverse faulting regime to strike-slip faulting regime with depth. In the reservoir section, the strike-slip faulting regime was interpreted. The contrast in the magnitude of Shmin between the reservoir section and the intervals above and below the reservoir is not significant. The direction of the minimum principal stress (S3) in the reservoir region is shown in Fig. 12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Spatial distribution of the minimum horizontal stress directions within the Onnagawa Formation (red horizon). The full stress tensor is derived through a largescale finite element simulation and calibrated with logs, core data and borehole images.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Spatial distribution of the minimum horizontal stress directions within the Onnagawa Formation (red horizon). The full stress tensor is derived through a largescale finite element simulation and calibrated with logs, core data and borehole images.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The general workflow adopted in this paper is illustrated in Fig. 13. Starting from a model calibrated to production data, opportunities indexes are calculated based on simulation and reservoir properties. All maps are then grouped into two main maps, a reservoir opportunity index (Eq.1) and a simulation opportunity index (Eq.5) maps. A global AOI is identified based on a cross plot reservoir vs simulation opportunity indexes as shown in Fig. 14. Filtering by considering a threshold (shown in blue top-right of Fig. 14), leads to a localized AOI bounded by two polygons as shown in Fig. 15 (left).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Opportunity-index based infill well placement workflow.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Opportunity-index based infill well placement workflow.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The general workflow adopted in this paper is illustrated in Fig. 13. Starting from a model calibrated to production data, opportunities indexes are calculated based on simulation and reservoir properties. All maps are then grouped into two main maps, a reservoir opportunity index (Eq.1) and a simulation opportunity index (Eq.5) maps. A global AOI is identified based on a cross plot reservoir vs simulation opportunity indexes as shown in Fig. 14. Filtering by considering a threshold (shown in blue top-right of Fig. 14), leads to a localized AOI bounded by two polygons as shown in Fig. 15 (left).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Cross Plot identify the area of interest (AOI) by using cell-based Reservoir opportunity index (ROI) in x-axis vs. simulation opportunity index (SOI) in the y-axis.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross Plot identify the area of interest (AOI) by using cell-based Reservoir opportunity index (ROI) in x-axis vs. simulation opportunity index (SOI) in the y-axis.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The general workflow adopted in this paper is illustrated in Fig. 13. Starting from a model calibrated to production data, opportunities indexes are calculated based on simulation and reservoir properties. All maps are then grouped into two main maps, a reservoir opportunity index (Eq.1) and a simulation opportunity index (Eq.5) maps. A global AOI is identified based on a cross plot reservoir vs simulation opportunity indexes as shown in Fig. 14. Filtering by considering a threshold (shown in blue top-right of Fig. 14), leads to a localized AOI bounded by two polygons as shown in Fig. 15 (left).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: LHS illustrates the area of interest based on filtered opportunity indexes maps (black dot show past producers). Because of the Kita-Akita heterogeneous sandstone distribution, identification of connected volumes is necessary. RHS shows connected volume within calculated AOI. Each color shows the ranking of large volumes.

formatted-caption.caption-text: LHS illustrates the area of interest based on filtered opportunity indexes maps (black dot show past producers). Because of the Kita-Akita heterogeneous sandstone distribution, identification of connected volumes is necessary. RHS shows connected volume within calculated AOI. Each color shows the ranking of large volumes.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Considering the AOI shown in Fig. 15 (left), we attempted a brute force optimization by sampling all possible infill well locations in Fig. 16 (left). To avoid drilling collision with plugged and abandoned producers, 50 meter radius of the investigation was avoided to set up a new well. All sandstone connected zone of the created infill wells are then perforated and reservoir simulation was performed. After all well production profiles of each infill well location are sorted, the best infill location is selected shown in Fig. 16 (right).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Screening for optimal well within the AOI (left). Black dots show potential new well. Reservoir simulation was conducted in all potential well and ranked. Note considering potential collision with past producers, 50 meter radius of the investigation was avoided to set up a new well. RHS illustrates the best infill well among the past producers.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Screening for optimal well within the AOI (left). Black dots show potential new well. Reservoir simulation was conducted in all potential well and ranked. Note considering potential collision with past producers, 50 meter radius of the investigation was avoided to set up a new well. RHS illustrates the best infill well among the past producers.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 17 shows the mud weight window in the reservoir section for wells to NE-SW (left) and NW-SE (right) directions. Here, the lower limit of the window is the higher value between pore pressure and mud weight to prevent any borehole breakout to minimize the risk due to wellbore instability from drilling a well to landing completion assembly. As shown in the figure, the mud weight window of a well along the NE-SW direction is narrower than one of a well along the NW-SE direction. Since there are some sporadic intervals in which more than 1.2 SG mud weight is required as the lower limit, the mud weight window in the NE-SW direction is narrower, with range from 1.37 to 1.47 SG.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Mud weight window in reservoir section. LHS shows NE-SW direction (along with Shmin, which is favorable condition for hydraulic fracturing). RHS shows NW-SE direction (along with Shmax,)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mud weight window in reservoir section. LHS shows NE-SW direction (along with Shmin, which is favorable condition for hydraulic fracturing). RHS shows NW-SE direction (along with Shmax,)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Considering the Kita-Akita thin layered reservoir, two types of deviated wells were then defined and compared. One is highly deviated well which enable to penetrate each layer efficiently. Another is fully horizontal penetration along with a specific layer target. Fig. 18 illustrates two lateral placement and reservoir contact. It is expected that highly deviated well (Fig 17, left) which is designed to penetrate all sand connected layers will have better performance. Once a motherbore set, fishbone sub or multi-fracturing is modeled and added.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Mother bore well placement. LHS illustrates horizontal well placement along with a best layer. RHS shows highly deviated well where all potential sand layers are penetrated to maximize the reservoir contact. Horizontal motherbore placement Highly deviated motherbore placement

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mother bore well placement. LHS illustrates horizontal well placement along with a best layer. RHS shows highly deviated well where all potential sand layers are penetrated to maximize the reservoir contact. Horizontal motherbore placement Highly deviated motherbore placement

linkTarget.anchoringText: A hole diameter of each lateral is about 50 mm and these laterals could be extended up to 100 m by a jetting as the schematic shown in Fig 19. RD operation first anchors the deflector at the target formation by use of coiled tubing, then a special casing cutter mill the casing and cement. A high-pressure hose and jet bit run into the hole and drill a formation by jetting with pumping a fluid (Bin et al. 2016). RHS of the figure illustrates the features of jet nozzle.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Radial Drilling Schematics (LHS) and penetration image by mechanical jetting (RHS, Ragab et al., 2013 ).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Radial Drilling Schematics (LHS) and penetration image by mechanical jetting (RHS, Ragab et al., 2013 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Ragab et al., 2013
S. Ragab , M. Adel , and A. M. Kamel
2013. Radial drilling technique for improving well productivity in petrobel-egypt. Paper SPE 164773 presented at the North Africa Technical Conference and Exhibition, Cairo, Egypt, 15-17 April . DOI: https://doi.org/10.2118/164773-MS

linkTarget.anchoringText: Similarly, the other two laterals are also drilled at a deeper depth. The mainbore is cased by 7" casing thus a reservoir fluid is produced only from the four horizontal laterals. Fig. 20 shows a FEM mesh created for the radial drilling completion. The model is made of 10 node tetrahedral elements with approximately 3 million nodes.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: 3D FEM mesh of radial drilling completion with 180 deg. phasing.

formatted-caption.caption-text: 3D FEM mesh of radial drilling completion with 180 deg. phasing.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this study, it is also assumed that the reservoir permeability is 10 md (isotropic) and the fluid viscosity and formation volume factor are 1 cp and 1.0 rb/stb, respectively. A steady-state flow simulation result is presented in Fig. 21. The pressure contour plot clearly shows that the four laterals effectively drains the reservoir fluid deep from the formation. In this case, the productivity index for the radial drilling well is estimated to be 3.87 stbpd/psi.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Simulated pressure contour plot for radial drilling completion.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated pressure contour plot for radial drilling completion.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 22 shows skin factors for radial drilling completions calculated by the Karakas and Tariq's perforation semianalytical skin model (Karakas and Tariq, 1991). For comparison, a skin value estimated by the 3D FEM model is also plotted for the effective lateral spacing, hlat of 32.8 ft (10 m). As shown in the figure, both analytical and numerical models match very well. This comparison ensures that radial drilling skin factors can be accurately predicted by the Karakas and Tariq's model. It should be noted that in the above calculations, the horizontal laterals are assumed to have infinite conductivity (i.e., no frictional pressure drop inside the lateral).

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Skin type curves for radial drilling completions using Karakas and Tariq's perforation skin factor model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Skin type curves for radial drilling completions using Karakas and Tariq's perforation skin factor model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this study, three RD settings are considered. Fig. 23 shows the patterns where radial drilling completions are designed in a vertical well identified in infill well placement section. Each RD lateral is 100 m long with the 2"-OD. To be conservative, these radial drilling cases are completed without perforation in non-RD penetrated sand layers thus a production flow is only from radial laterals. Four laterals of single RD system is placed in a best layer, whereas 45 degree angular and dual RD system are expected to contact more sandface.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Each schematic of Radial drilling system in wellbore modeling. Note 45 deg angular lateral system are practically no field case but theoretically modeled for a comparison. Single system (4 laterals) 45 deg angular lateral (4 laterals) Dual system (2 × 4 laterals)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Each schematic of Radial drilling system in wellbore modeling. Note 45 deg angular lateral system are practically no field case but theoretically modeled for a comparison. Single system (4 laterals) 45 deg angular lateral (4 laterals) Dual system (2 × 4 laterals)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig.24 shows a simulated ten years cumulative production profile of each RD wellbore modeling, where each profile was normalized based on the cased and perforated vertical well identified in the infill well placement section. Same reservoir properties and simulation setting as calibrated in history-matched model was used. As seen, channel reservoir case illustrates both dual and 45 degree angular lateral RD system cases outperform the cased and perforated vertical well case because the lateral contributes to secure enough reservoir contacts.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: RD simulation result in Channel reservoir and Sheet reservoir case. Normalized Cumulative Production (Channel) Normalized Cumulative Production (Sheet)

formatted-caption.caption-text: RD simulation result in Channel reservoir and Sheet reservoir case. Normalized Cumulative Production (Channel) Normalized Cumulative Production (Sheet)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The technology comprises MST subs that houses three small-diameter (hole size OD: 013 mm; bit size OD: 8 mm), high-strength tubes called needles up to approximately 35 ft (10 m). Each needle has a drill bit on the formation end and a turbine on the casing end as shown in Fig. 25. The laterals are drilled simultaneously form the openhole liner in a relatively short pumping operation (Torvund et al, 2016). If a formation is limestone, acid jetting is mostly used and four needles are allowed in each sub.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: MST sub assembly (LHS,Torvund et al. 2016 ) and a penetration and placement image of small-diameter needles with drill bits as integral parts of an openhole liner (RHS, Fishbones)

formatted-caption.caption-text: MST sub assembly (LHS,Torvund et al. 2016 ) and a penetration and placement image of small-diameter needles with drill bits as integral parts of an openhole liner (RHS, Fishbones)

linkTarget.bib:
Torvund et al., 2016
S. Torvund , K. Stene , H. Jensaas , E. Renli , J. K. Rice , and T. Jorgensen
2016. First Installation of Multilateral Drilling Stimulation Technology in Tight Sandstone Formation.. Paper SPE 180390 presented at SPE Western Regional Meeting, Anchorage, Alaska, 23-26 May. DOI: https://doi.org/10.2118/180390-MS.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Following the previous radial drilling performance evaluation, a similar FEM modeling study was done for fishbone drilling. For the fishbone case, it is assumed that the 5.5"-diameter fishbone liner system is installed in a 8.5"-diameter horizontal borehole. In the 80 ft lateral section, two subs are installed thus sub spacing assumes to be 40 ft. Each fishbone sub has three 32.8'-length needles with 120 deg. phasing. The effective diameter of the holes created by the drilling from the needle end is assumed to be 0.512". The fishbone subs are oriented in an alternative way. Fig. 26 shows a FEM mesh created for the fishbone liner completion (approximately 0.5 million nodes) used in this study.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: 3D FEM mesh of fishbone completion with 120 deg. phasing (three needles per sub).

formatted-caption.caption-text: 3D FEM mesh of fishbone completion with 120 deg. phasing (three needles per sub).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Also we assume no frictional pressure drop in the needle annuli between the drilled hole and the fishbone needle. The drainage pattern estimated from the FEM model is presented in Fig. 27. The productivity index for the fishbone well is estimated to be 0.55 stbpd/psi per 80 ft horizontal well length (i.e., 2 subs). If the filter cake of the mainbore is completely cleaned up, it can contribute to inflow form the reservoir. In this case, the productivity index estimated from the simulation model becomes 0.59 stbpd/psi per 80 ft horizontal well length.

image-wrap.label: Figure 27
image-wrap.caption: Simulated pressure contour plot for fishbone completion.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated pressure contour plot for fishbone completion.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 28 shows skin factors for fishbone completions calculated by the Karakas and Tariq's model. For comparison, skin values estimated by the 3D FEM model is also plotted for 120 deg phasing cases. The numerical model calculates skin values of −1.7 and −2.4 for needle only and needle + mainbore cases, respectively. These skin values are slightly better than one predicted by the Karakas and Tariq's model (S =−1.44), especially for the needle + mainbore case. The additional inflow from the mainbore causes higher well productivity. But for practical use, the Karakas and Tariq's skin factor model can be used for rough skin estimations of fishbone completions.

image-wrap.label: Figure 28
image-wrap.caption: Skin type curves for fishbone completions using Karakas and Tariq's perforation skin factor model.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Skin type curves for fishbone completions using Karakas and Tariq's perforation skin factor model.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The same procedure as described in radial drilling simulation part was applied for fishbone drilling completions in both 3D channel and sheet reservoir models. Two deviated wellbore setting presented in Fig. 18 were used as a main bore and each production performance from the deviated and a horizontal well with openhole completions are compared (LHS of Fig. 29). Fishbone sub and needles are placed in the two well cases as shown in RHS of Fig. 29, which illustrates fishbone completions designed for both deviated and horizontal wells with 10 meter fishbone needle length and the OD-0.315".

image-wrap.label: Figure 29
image-wrap.caption: Deviated and horizontal wells designed with openhole completions (LHS), and fishbone completions added in the main bore (RHS)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Deviated and horizontal wells designed with openhole completions (LHS), and fishbone completions added in the main bore (RHS)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Deviated and horizontal wells designed with openhole completions
fishbone completions added in the main bore

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 30 shows a simulated ten years cumulative production of each openhole well with and without fishbone modeling, where each profile was normalized based on the openhole horizontal well. Same reservoir properties and simulation setting as calibrated in history-matched model was used. As seen in the figure, channel reservoir case highlights the highly deviated well which intends to penetrate all sand layers had 20 % increase in cumulative production compared to the horizontal well which intends to penetrate most good layer only.

image-wrap.label: Figure 30
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative production profile normalized by horizontal OH well w/o Fishbone sub in channel reservoir. Normalized Cumulative Production (Channel) Normalized Cumulative Production (Sheet)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative production profile normalized by horizontal OH well w/o Fishbone sub in channel reservoir. Normalized Cumulative Production (Channel) Normalized Cumulative Production (Sheet)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using that information, we firstly looked back the past treated hydraulic fracturing job in created 1D MEM based on goemchanical properties taken by the pilot-hole program. Fig. 31 illustrates fracture propagation result after closure. Since the job size in 1960s were much smaller proppant volume than today (Table 4), dimensionless conductivity was calculated almost zero. It is expected that a larger volume fracturing jobs would enhance well performance under the current sitation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 31
image-wrap.caption: Conductivity profile after closure based on 1D MEM which reproduced the past 1960s fracturing job.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Conductivity profile after closure based on 1D MEM which reproduced the past 1960s fracturing job.

linkTarget.anchoringText: For a sand, dehaydration impact is larger due to higher permeability thus fracture tip (approximately 0.5 inch) become dry zone. In this area, fracuturing polymer is clogged and the pressure is not propagated. For a shale, due to lower permeability, fluid loss is small enough, thereore, dehydration zone is smaller (0.1 to 0.2 inch). In our sensitivity trial in 1D MEM, increasing the fracture toughness results in less fracture length and higher fracture height as shown in Fig 32.

image-wrap.label: Figure 32
image-wrap.caption: Planar 3D Fracture geometry profile (fracture width) in fracture toughness setting in geomechanical experiment result (LHS) and apparent fracture toughness case (RHS).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Planar 3D Fracture geometry profile (fracture width) in fracture toughness setting in geomechanical experiment result (LHS) and apparent fracture toughness case (RHS).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Another unique setting in this reservoir is that 3D MEM initialization was performed after the reservoir pressure depleted from past producers, which may cause depletion induced stress in the reservoir as shown in Fig. 33. It may contribute to build enough barriers to contain a hydraulic fracture propagation. The result of the 3D MEM initialization, however, Shmin change was confirmed only 10 to 15 bar. Therefore, enough barrier was not generated from the depletion effect, therefore height growth issue should be considered for a fracturing design.

image-wrap.label: Figure 33
image-wrap.caption: LHS illustrates an example of reservoir pressure depletion induded stress change (original in blue and after depletion in red). RHS shows Shmin stress, reservoir pressure profile as well as difference between original reservoir and depleted within fine layers in VIII zone of Onagawa formation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: LHS illustrates an example of reservoir pressure depletion induded stress change (original in blue and after depletion in red). RHS shows Shmin stress, reservoir pressure profile as well as difference between original reservoir and depleted within fine layers in VIII zone of Onagawa formation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: As seen in Fig. 34, the propped height is more contained in the same layer depth in 1D MEM when compared to the same fracture simulation running on the 3D MEM. This is because the vertical stress stays the same at any horizontal location. The simulations also suggest opposite fracture extention directions between these two models. In the 3D MEM case, higher stress zones exist down dip of fracture, and this works as a barrier of the fracture propagation in that direction.

image-wrap.label: Figure 34
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of fracture propagation in 3D MEM grid and 1D MEM grid (cross sectional view). (a) Fracture propagation in 3D MEM Grid (b) Fracture propagation in 1D MEM Grid

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of fracture propagation in 3D MEM grid and 1D MEM grid (cross sectional view). (a) Fracture propagation in 3D MEM Grid (b) Fracture propagation in 1D MEM Grid

linkTarget.anchoringText: Two hyfraulic fracture simulation cases are defined in a vertical and a horizontal well. A single stage hydraulic fracture was designed in the vertical well. Aslo 5 stages, 100 m spacing fracturing was designed in the horizontal well oriented in Shmin direction for the comparison. The resultant hydraulic fracture propagation by the Planar 3D model in a 3D MEM is shown in Fig. 35.

image-wrap.label: Figure 35
image-wrap.caption: Propagation geometry and conductivity profile based on the job design in vertical well and horizontal well in channel reservoir model. (a) Vertical well hydraulic fracturing (b) 5 stage HF in horizontal wellpropagation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Propagation geometry and conductivity profile based on the job design in vertical well and horizontal well in channel reservoir model. (a) Vertical well hydraulic fracturing (b) 5 stage HF in horizontal wellpropagation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 36 shows a simulated ten years cumulative production of cased hole and perforated vertical well and horizontal well as well as fractured vertical and horizontal well. Each profile was normalized based on the cased and perforated vertical well. Same reservoir properties and simulation setting as calibrated in history-matched model was used. In the channel reservoir case where the horizontal connectivity is relatively poor due to their horizontally interspersed distribution, the fracture plays an important role to connect each lenticular reservoir pool as the image is shown in Fig. 37.

image-wrap.label: Figure 36
image-wrap.caption: The reservoir simulation results in chanel reservoir and sheet reservoir case. Normalized Cumulative Production (Channel) Normalized Cumulative Production (Sheet)

formatted-caption.caption-text: The reservoir simulation results in chanel reservoir and sheet reservoir case. Normalized Cumulative Production (Channel) Normalized Cumulative Production (Sheet)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 36 shows a simulated ten years cumulative production of cased hole and perforated vertical well and horizontal well as well as fractured vertical and horizontal well. Each profile was normalized based on the cased and perforated vertical well. Same reservoir properties and simulation setting as calibrated in history-matched model was used. In the channel reservoir case where the horizontal connectivity is relatively poor due to their horizontally interspersed distribution, the fracture plays an important role to connect each lenticular reservoir pool as the image is shown in Fig. 37.

image-wrap.label: Figure 37
image-wrap.caption: LHS multiple fracture placement in the sector model, crossing mobile oil saturated zone. RHS lenticular sand image.

formatted-caption.caption-text: LHS multiple fracture placement in the sector model, crossing mobile oil saturated zone. RHS lenticular sand image.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Finally, each screening result was summarized based on the screening matrix. Fig. 38 shows normalized capital expenditures of each completion and stimulation method. The cost is normalizaed by the least capital expenditure (in this case, fishbone 5 sub case). Note that all information is collected in October 2017 and is subject to change in current market condition. Also the trend varies in other locations and countries. It is highlighted in our case that coiled tubing drilling in deviated lateral section was not cost-effective compared to other stimulation types.

image-wrap.label: Figure 38
image-wrap.caption: Normalized well completion and stimulation cost in Kita-Akita case. On top of this, drilling cost is added to a capital expenditure to perform an economics evaluation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Normalized well completion and stimulation cost in Kita-Akita case. On top of this, drilling cost is added to a capital expenditure to perform an economics evaluation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Final screening summary is summarized in Fig. 39 and Table 5. Each maturity, applicability, productivity, and economics are normalized based on cased and perforated vertical well performance. In the study, multistage hydraulic fracturing treatment is still the most brute way to maximize a contact area and improve recovery, however, fracturing treatment cost worsen the economics.

image-wrap.label: Figure 39
image-wrap.caption: Score matrix comparative result. Each case was plot. LHS shows channel sand case. RHS shows sheet sand case. Score Matrix (Channel Model) Score Matrix (Sheet Model)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Score matrix comparative result. Each case was plot. LHS shows channel sand case. RHS shows sheet sand case. Score Matrix (Channel Model) Score Matrix (Sheet Model)
